newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: PRESS DIGEST - Czech Republic - April 1.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Czech Republic - April 1.

text.p: HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - The decrease in demand for electricity confirmed the slowing tempo of the Czech economy. Demand for electricity from the industrial sector rose by 0.4 percent. Overall demand increased by 3.8 percent. This was primarily due to an increase in household consumption which rose 7.8 percent.

- Liquidation of Agrobanka would cost taxpayers far more money than selling the institution to strategic investors. A portion of investors linked to Motoinvest are calling for the liquidaton. The forced administrator of Agrobanka, Jiri Klumpar at the end of last week rejected the notion that the bank will be liquidated.

- The industry and trade ministry has developed a clear plan of how to complete privatisation of the coal and petrochemical industries. The ministry has also formulated specific plans together with the finance ministry for privatising energy distributors.

MLADA FRONTA DNES - A five billion crown financial injection pledged by the health ministry to pharmaceutical suppliers may forestall the auctioning off of hospitals, however no one can guarantee that the crisis will not repeat itself in the future.
- Commercial banks will most likely not increase interest rates on depositors accounts.

- It is unclear who purchased a portion of the country's largest brewery, Plzenky Prazdroj. One of the largest shareholders, Ceska Pojistovna claims that it sold its shares in the brewery to Investicni a Postovni banka. The bank, however, refuses to acknowledge the transaction.
LIDOVE NOVINY - Leasing reached a total of nearly 46 billion crowns. This represented an increase of over two fifths from the previous year when leasing accounted for 32 billion crowns.
- Last week the value of shares ceased to decline. Most frequently traded shares experienced a marginal increase in value, however, it is premature to call this a growth period.
PRAVO - According to Tomas Tichy, chairman of the Czech gas and oil association, all estimates confirm that gas consumption in the Czech Republic will increase 50 percent over the next fifteen years.
